titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0937, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel lectionary leaves in Greek. Contain portions of the Matthean section of the Synaxarion. Passages begin with the formula τω καιρω εκεινω (On a certain occasion) or ειπεν ο κυριος (The Lord said). Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 41 and Ms. 939b.

initials.p: Major initials (40-50 mm) set off from the text in black or red. Instances of the initial T (tau) embellished with barbs, beads, ribbons, or a combination of motifs.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in black ink (some flaking).
Punctuation includes the cross (full stop), middle point, comma, and marks of elision and interrogation.

textDivisions.p: Headings in uncial script in red (faded).

condition.p: Random holes. Edges are irregular. Some leaves trimmed resulting in the loss of text written in the margins.

binding.p: Bound by R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company in dark blue linen over cardboard. Front cover label in gilt: Four Lectionary Leaves (Matthew) XIV cent.

origin.p: The manuscript to which the present leaves belonged is judged to have been written in the 14th century in Italy.

provenance.p: Late medieval to early 20th century provenance unknown. Belonged to Harold Rideout Willoughby (1890-1962), professor in the University of Chicago's Divinity School. Mr. Willoughby purchased the leaves from Philip C. Duschnes (New York), ca. 1938.

acquisition.p: Gift of Harold R. Willoughby to the University of Chicago, November 1938.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: Gospel lectionary leaves in Greek. Contain portions of the Matthean section of the Synaxarion. Passages begin with the formula τω καιρω εκεινω (On a certain occasion) or ειπεν ο κυριος (The Lord said). Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 41 and Ms. 939b.

msItem.summary: Monday, Week 6 after Pentecost, Matthew 13:15-22 (lacking, begins with οφθαλμουσ).

msItem.rubric: εκ του κατα Ματθαιον (From the Gospel according to Matthew).

msItem.summary: Thursday, Week 6 after Pentecost, Matthew 13:36-43 (lacking, ends with ο εχων).
msItem.note: Between fols. [2] and [3], readings lost for Friday, Week 6 after Pentecost, and part of Monday, Week 7 after Pentecost.

msItem.summary: Monday, Week 7 after Pentecost, Matthew 13:58 ((lacking, begins with [ε]ποιησεν).
Friday, Week 7 after Pentecost, Matthew 15:29-[31] (lacking, ends at verse 29 with εκει).
